newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore's PCS secures 80-pct naphtha on term.
newsitem.headline: Singapore's PCS secures 80-pct naphtha on term.

text.p: The Petrochemical Corporation of Singapore (PCS) has secured term contracts for the supply of up to 80 percent of naphtha feedstock needed for its new 515,000 tonne per year ethylene plant due to start up in April, a senior company official said on Tuesday.
"In anticipation of next year's feedstock requirement, we have already increased the intake quantities in the term contracts this year," managing director Takayuki Okada told Reuters in an interview.
The company's annual demand for naphtha following the start up of the new plant will increase from close to 1 million tonnes (24,600 barrels-per-day) to around 2.5 million tonnes (62,000 bpd).
PCS currently operates a 450,000 tonne per year ethylene plant at Pulau Ayer Merbau, one of a group of small islands off the southern coast of Singapore.
The plant is connected by pipeline to two oil refineries, the 280,000-bpd Singapore Refining Co (SRC) plant and Esso Singapore's 230,00-bpd refinery.

SRC is joint-venture between Singapore Petroleum Co, British Petroleum and Caltex, the joint-venture between majors Chevron Corp and Texaco Inc. Okada said the company "will also buy spot cargoes as and when needed to supplement our requirement".

To strengthen the company's buying position, PCS has also leased substantial storage space at the adjoining 600,000 cubic metre independent tank farm operated by Oil Tanking Singapore Limited at Pulau Seraya.
The storage space gives PCS "extra access to the outside market", Okada said.
PCS will keep the volume of naphtha imported from the Gulf steady at about 10 percent of its requirements even after the new plant is operational, he said.
The company also has the flexibility to use liquified petroleum gas (LPG) up to about 20 percent of the total feedstock in place of naphtha if the economics make it worthwhile, Okada added.
